posts.title: Writing Technical Content When You're Too Tired to Be Funny
posts.description: It's hour 6 of debugging. The bug is fixed. This is not the time to write something entertaining—but it is the perfect time to write something useful. Here's the two-pass approach to technical blogging.
posts.linkedInHook:
It's 11:47 PM. The bug is fixed. I have 43 browser tabs open and my coffee went cold two hours ago.

This is not the time to write something entertaining.

But it IS the perfect time to write something useful.

Most of my 'entertaining' technical posts started as exhausted notes at unreasonable hours. The wit wasn't there originally. The analogies came later.

Capture the details while they're fresh. Add the humor when you can actually be funny.

The entertaining version is always a second pass.

posts.title: Schema-Aware EF Core Migrations: One Migration Set, Multiple Environments
posts.description: EF Core migrations don't natively support runtime schema selection. Here's how to intercept migration operations and inject the correct schema for local, dev, staging, and production.
posts.linkedInHook:
"Which environment did that migration just run against?"

I stared at Slack with that sinking feeling. EF Core migrations don't support runtime schema selection—the schema is baked in when you generate the migration.

So I built a custom SQL generator that intercepts operations mid-flight and injects the correct schema.

Now: same migrations, different schemas. [local], [dev], [stg], [dbo]. No more "wait, which one did I just hit?" moments.

Part 3 of the Enterprise Database Patterns series.

posts.title: Database-Backed Encrypted Configuration: Stop Committing Secrets
posts.description: I once committed an API key to a public repo at 3 AM. That incident taught me secrets in source control are a when problem, not an if problem. Here's the pattern that makes the mistake impossible.
posts.linkedInHook:
I once committed an API key to a public GitHub repo. It was 3 AM. The deploy was "almost done."

Three hours later, my inbox was full of AWS alerts.

That incident taught me: secrets in source control are a WHEN problem, not an IF problem.

So I built database-backed configuration with AES-256-GCM encryption. The key file is gitignored. Secrets are encrypted at rest. Your code uses IConfiguration normally—it just works.

Part 2 of the Enterprise Database Patterns series.

posts.title: Modern Database Testing: Why InMemory Databases Lie To You
posts.description: My test passed locally and caught fire in staging. That's when I learned UseInMemoryDatabase() is like a friend who tells you that outfit looks great when it definitely does not.
posts.linkedInHook:
The test passed. Ship it, right?

Then I deployed to staging and watched everything catch fire. The LINQ query that worked against UseInMemoryDatabase() generated SQL that SQL Server refused to execute.

InMemory databases lie to you. They're fast and convenient, like a friend who tells you that outfit looks great when it definitely does not.

The fix: real SQL Server + Respawn. ~20ms resets instead of ~1000ms. When tests pass now, I actually believe them.

Part 1 of the Enterprise Database Patterns series.

posts.title: CI/CD Version Verification: Trust But Verify Your Deployments
posts.description: MSDeploy can return success even when your app fails to start. Here's how to add version endpoints and automated verification to catch those ghost deployments before your users do.
posts.linkedInHook:
Your deploy succeeded. But did it *actually* work?

MSDeploy syncs files successfully, but that doesn't mean your app is healthy. Config might be wrong. Database might not connect. App might crash on startup.

The fix: version endpoints that return what's actually running, and a verify job that compares it to what you just deployed.

Bonus: include uptime in the response. If it shows 0:00:05 when you expected hours, something restarted unexpectedly.

Version endpoints are cheap insurance. A few minutes of setup saves hours of 'why isn't my code deployed?' debugging.

posts.title: The Pending Count That Wouldn't Stay: A MAUI Blazor Debugging Marathon
posts.description: What started as 'the pending count resets to zero' turned into a 7+ hour journey through Blazor component lifecycle, INotifyPropertyChanged, MAUI deployment quirks, MinVer versioning, and multi-environment debugging.
posts.linkedInHook:
Navigate away and back. The pending count is 0.

The data was still there. The count just wasn't updating.

7+ hours later, I found the root cause: two services were both calling SetPendingCount() with their own count. LoggingService set it to 3, then SyncService immediately overwrote it with 0.

The fix: separate counts per service, INotifyPropertyChanged for granular updates, and Blazor components that subscribe to changes.

Plus 4 bonus rabbit holes: ObjectDisposedException, Debug APKs that won't start, MinVer returning 0.0.0, and syncing to the wrong server.

Sometimes a 'quick test' is anything but.

posts.title: Breaking Circular Dependencies with SOLID Principles
posts.description: When two services need each other, it's tempting to reach for IServiceProvider and lazy loading. But that quick fix hides architectural wounds. Here's how extracting shared concerns breaks the cycle properly.
posts.linkedInHook:
The build failed. Circular dependency detected.

Two services needed each other. SyncService logs operations. LoggingService syncs logs. Classic tangle.

The quick fix: IServiceProvider + lazy loading. It compiles. It runs.

The problem: hidden dependencies, testing nightmares, and the architectural wound stays open.

The real fix: extract the shared concern. Create ISyncStatusService to own the state both services need. Now they depend on the abstraction, not each other.

30 minutes longer. Pays dividends forever.

posts.title: Automatic Semantic Versioning with MinVer: Never Manually Bump Again
posts.description: Version numbers in three .csproj files, remembering to create git tags, hoping you didn't fat-finger 0.9.1 as 0.91. MinVer eliminates all of it by deriving versions from git tags automatically.
posts.linkedInHook:
I used to dread version bumps. Update three .csproj files, create a git tag, hope I didn't fat-finger 0.9.1 as 0.91.

Then I discovered MinVer. Now I never manually set a version number.

The version IS the git tag. MinVer reads your git history and calculates the version at build time. Developers commit code. Release pipelines create tags. The cycle continues automatically.

One Directory.Build.props file. Zero manual edits. Zero version mismatches.

posts.title: Tracer Bullet Development: How Error Logging Proved My Entire Sync Architecture
posts.description: Before building months of features, I built one thing: error logging. It proved the entire Mobile → API → Database → Web Admin pipeline worked—and found four bugs that would have been painful later.
posts.linkedInHook:
How do you know your architecture works before building months of features?

Build a tracer bullet. One thin, end-to-end implementation that proves the whole pipeline.

I chose error logging. Simple data, no business rules, but it touches every layer: Mobile → API → Database → Web Admin.

In one day, I validated 11 integration points. And found 4 bugs that would have been painful to debug in complex features.

Now every new feature is 'just another endpoint' instead of 'I hope this fits together.'

posts.title: Testing Non-Virtual Members: When Moq Can't Help and SOLID Saves the Day
posts.description: Moq throws NotSupportedException on NavigationManager.Uri because it's not virtual. Here's why that connects to SOLID principles, and two patterns to test it anyway.
posts.linkedInHook:
Moq threw NotSupportedException: 'Non-overridable members may not be used in setup expressions.'

NavigationManager.Uri isn't virtual. Microsoft chose safety over testability—you can't bypass their initialization logic.

This is SOLID in action. LSP says subclasses should be substitutable. Microsoft said 'we don't trust your substitution here.'

Two workarounds: inherit and override protected methods, or wrap it in your own interface. Both work. Choose based on what you're testing.

posts.title: NavigationManager 'Not Initialized' - The MAUI Blazor Hybrid Gotcha
posts.description: Your error boundary works in Blazor WASM but crashes in MAUI Hybrid with 'WebViewNavigationManager has not been initialized.' Here's why and how to fix it.
posts.linkedInHook:
Built an error boundary that worked perfectly in Blazor WASM. Deployed to MAUI Hybrid on Android. Immediate crash:

'WebViewNavigationManager has not been initialized.'

The issue: in MAUI, NavigationManager wraps a native WebView. During early error handling, the WebView isn't ready yet. Accessing .Uri throws.

The fix is embarrassingly simple: wrap it in try-catch. Defensive programming wins again.

posts.title: Error Boundaries That Don't Trap Users: A UX Lesson in Blazor
posts.description: Your Blazor ErrorBoundary catches the error but blocks the user's escape route. They can't navigate away. Here's how to make error boundaries recover on navigation.
posts.linkedInHook:
Added an ErrorBoundary to my Blazor app. Caught errors, showed a nice message. Great!

Then a user hit an error and tried to navigate away. Nothing happened. They were trapped.

The error boundary was a cage, not a safety net.

The fix: subscribe to NavigationManager.LocationChanged and call Recover() when the user navigates. Now errors don't break navigation.

Rule: errors should never block the user's escape route.

posts.title: Phone-Friendly Reference IDs: Why Crockford Base32 is Perfect for Support
posts.description: GUIDs over the phone are a nightmare. 'Is that zero or the letter O?' Douglas Crockford's Base32 encoding removes ambiguous characters entirely.
posts.linkedInHook:
User calls support: 'My error code is seven-eff-three-ay-nine-one-bee-zero...'

Support: 'Is that a zero or the letter O?'

User: 'Um...'

This is why Douglas Crockford designed a Base32 encoding that removes confusing characters. No I, L, O, or U.

Now error codes like ERR-QB20S0VJ are unambiguous. Users can even use NATO phonetic alphabet naturally.

Small design choice. Big difference in real-world support.

posts.title: The IIS app_offline.htm Deployment Trick
posts.description: Tired of ERROR_FILE_IN_USE when deploying to IIS? One file stops your app, releases all locks, and shows users a maintenance page. Here's how to add it to your deployment scripts.
posts.linkedInHook:
Deploying to IIS and hitting ERROR_FILE_IN_USE is infuriating. The app is running, IIS has file locks, MSDeploy fails. I'd been working around this with retry loops and manual FTP deletions.

Turns out there's a feature that's been in IIS all along: app_offline.htm.

Drop that file in your app root and IIS immediately stops the app, releases all locks, and serves a maintenance page. Deploy your files. Delete the file. App restarts.

One file. No more lock errors.

posts.title: Environment-Specific EF Core Migrations with SQL Scripts
posts.description: EF Core migrations run the same code everywhere, but real apps need different seed data per environment. Here's a convention-based pattern that loads the right SQL script automatically.
posts.linkedInHook:
EF Core migrations are great for schema changes, but they run the same code everywhere. Real apps need different seed data per environment—demo users in dev, minimal data in staging, nothing in production.

The typical fix is wrapping everything in if (Environment.IsDevelopment()) checks. That gets ugly fast.

Here's a cleaner pattern: convention-based SQL scripts that load automatically based on environment. Script.dev.sql for dev, Script.prod.sql for production. The migration code stays simple.

posts.title: Upgrading Certbot to Wildcard Certificates
posts.description: My SSL setup worked great until I needed subdomains for a multi-tenant SaaS. One wildcard certificate covers them all—but Certbot's upgrade path has some gotchas.
posts.linkedInHook:
My SSL automation was humming along—until I needed subdomains for a multi-tenant SaaS app. Adding each one manually meant regenerating certs every time a client onboarded.

Solution: wildcard certificates. One cert covers *.domain.com.

But Certbot doesn't just upgrade in place. It creates a new cert with a -0001 suffix. And the rename command doesn't exist in older versions. Here's how to handle it cleanly.

posts.title: Tailwind's Hidden Gotchas: Dynamic Classes and @layer

Tailwind's JIT compiler is amazing until it silently ignores your classes. Built a progress bar component with dynamic widths like `w-[${percent}%]`. None of them worked.

The JIT compiler only scans for complete class names in your source files. String concatenation breaks it. Here's what to do instead.

Had a worldbuilding breakthrough for the novel. What if Irish stone circles weren't just settings, but a neural network across the land?

The stones remember. They pass information. They've been watching for thousands of years. Suddenly the setting became a character.

posts.title: Show, Don't Tell (Even When It Hurts)
posts.description: The brutal revision where I cut every explanation of my supernatural forces—and learned to trust my readers.
posts.linkedInHook:
Did a brutal revision pass where I cut every explanation of my supernatural forces. Every 'the fire was judgment incarnate' became just the fire doing things.

It hurt. But readers don't need explanations—they need experiences. Learning to trust them.

posts.title: Finding the Voice
posts.description: How I stopped writing chatty demons and learned to ground the supernatural in universal human experience.
posts.linkedInHook:
Early drafts of my novel had chatty demons explaining everything. It read like a supernatural Wikipedia.

The fix was grounding the strange in the universal. That burning feeling when you're certain you're right? That exhaustion of judgment without mercy? Those are human experiences—even when they're literally on fire.

posts.title: Electric Fuel Pump Conversion: John Deere 318
posts.description: Replacing a failing vacuum fuel pump with an electric pump, and the relay wiring needed to make it work safely with the oil pressure switch.
posts.linkedInHook:
Fixed a failing fuel pump on the John Deere 318 by converting from vacuum to electric. The relay wiring to make it work safely with the oil pressure switch was the interesting part.

Documenting for anyone else with an old Onan engine.

posts.title: How Black Ember Began (Or: From Video Game Avatar to Literary Fiction)
posts.description: Every novel has an origin story. Mine started with a superhero game avatar, transformed when my dog died, and became literary dark fantasy.
posts.linkedInHook:
Every novel has an origin story. Mine started with a superhero game avatar called Black Ember—an Irish vigilante, sort of Batman meets Constantine.

Then my dog died. And the avatar became a novel about self-condemnation, mercy, and a spectral hound who watches across centuries.

Your first concept is rarely your final story.
